the only intramural competition
in lacrosse."

academic average of fraternity
men is slightly higher than the
average of Hopkins undergraduates as a whole. Tau Epsilon

Hopkins history department

awarded the Allan Nevins prize
by the American Society
of Historians. This organization
bestows the grant of $1000 for
the best submitted dissertation
in American Studies.
The prize is significant not
only for the affirmation of superior scholarship and for the
monetary stipend, but it may
foretell a meaningful career for
Mrs. Rose. The $1000 is donated
by ten publishing houses in New
York, one of which is most probable to publish the Thesis and

success and most thankful for
her apparently bright future.

extreme interest and devotion to
her studies. The winning dissertation was entitled Rehearsal for

group of islands off South Carolina where a peculiarly advanced

education took place during and
after the Civil War. She believes
this isolated, missionary attempt
to aid the negro, although rather
premature, was the basis for the
following period of reconstruction.

the only solution.

We wish to extend our heartiest congratulations,
both personal and editorial, to Keith Spalding, Secretary
of the University, on his appointment to the Presidency of
Franklin and Marshall College. In the seven years of his
stay at Hopkins Mr. Spalding has been a consistent, patient
and sympathetic friend of the undergraduate. Unobstrusively, but very effectively he has acted as a liaison between the
administration and the student body, always available to
lend his considerable judgement to any worthwhile project
and to help further it if possible.
We owe a special debt to Mr. Spalding because he has
voluntarily assumed the duties of unofficial advisor to the
News-Letter, meeting informally with the editors each week
His experience and
to discuss problems and projects.
advice has often helped to stabilize our somewhat erratic
course but never, even when he disagrees with us, has he
attempted to dictate policy.
This tact has extended to all phases of Mr. Spalding's
activities at Hopkins. He has filled a delicate position
with taste, prudence and a sincere interest in the good
of the 'University. We are sure that these excellent qualities
will lead him to success at Franklin and Marshall.

Can Fraternities Survive?
Second semester rushing this year may determine the
future of the fraternity system at the University. After a
semester with no formal rushing procedures, the individual fraternities now have the opportunity to demonstrate
whatever advantages they can offer Hopkins freshmen.
It would appear that freshmen will flock to the individual fraternity houses tonight and tomorrow night if not
just for curiosity, in an effort to join a social club which
will supplement the severely impersonal social life of
dormitory students.
While the social advantages of fraternities are greater
than those of the dormitory houses, they are also their
sorest point. In the past fraternities have found no moderation in their social programs. Either the programs have
been overabundant, detracting the fraternity membership
from the campus atmosphere, or they have been too sparse,
resulting in unsuccessful, overly expensive fraternity
groups.
The problem seems to be that fraternities have not
exploited their unique position and have not taken advantage of their abilities to supplement undergraduate life at
the University. They have a wonderful opportunity to
add to the humanistic traditions of university living by
providing the gemiitligkeit severely lacking in the comparatively cold atmosphere of the dormitories. While this
should he the primary effect of their social orientation,
it should not be their sole function.
Fraternities can implement the University atmosphere
not only through the support of campus events, but by
establishing an atmosphere more consistent with the
academic ethos of the University. Some fraternities have
attempted to do this and have, in effect, added much to
the advantages of group membership. They have sponsored plays downtown, concerts in the houses and informal
sessions with faculty members.
To assure themselves of future success they will have
to seriously attempt to balance social programs, to reconciliate the academic atmosphere and that of fraternalism,

they perform at present. If they cannot, they will ultimately fail and he replaced by other forms of social organization, or they will fall into dull mediocrity and exist hut
parasitically on the unique institution which they should
support and supplement.

Second semester rushing this year may determine the
future of the fraternity system at the University. After a
semester with no formal rushing procedures, the individual fraternities now have the opportunity to demonstrate
whatever advantages they can offer Hopkins freshmen.
It would appear that freshmen will flock to the individual fraternity houses tonight and tomorrow night if not
just for curiosity, in an effort to join a social club which
will supplement the severely impersonal social life of
dormitory students.
While the social advantages of fraternities are greater
than those of the dormitory houses, they are also their
sorest point. In the past fraternities have found no moderation in their social programs. Either the programs have
been overabundant, detracting the fraternity membership
from the campus atmosphere, or they have been too sparse,
resulting in unsuccessful, overly expensive fraternity
groups.
